Dear Ms. Prudhomme:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.

Sincerely,
Barbara A Cote, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents' needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
1

Allegation Youth sprayed staff member with ketchup, staff member then
grabbed the ketchup and wiped some of the ketchup that was on
the staff member’s jacket onto the youth. The on-call supervisor
then began to ask youth what their plan is, and youth then
complained that the staff member spit on youth’s face. The on-call
supervisor then grabbed a piece of paper towel and wiped off
youth’s face.
Investigation I learned this information after reading restraint reviews.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 19, 2025. Youth A described being mad and sprayed
ketchup around the house and on Staff 1. Youth A reported Staff
1 took the ketchup bottle and wiped ketchup on Youth A’s
stomach. Youth A stated Staff 1 said, “You want some ketchup,
here, now you know how it feels.” Youth A denied any other youth
saw Staff 1 wipe the ketchup on Youth A. Youth A stated he
thinks there was another staff that may have seen Staff 1 wipe the
ketchup on Youth A, but he was not positive.
Youth A reported he punched Staff 1 after Staff 1 wiped ketchup
on him. Youth A stated Staff 1 placed Youth A in a restraint and
Supervisor came to assist with the restraint. Youth A described
Supervisor yelling and when he was yelling, spit came out of
Supervisor’s mouth. Youth A stated, “it was not intentional, he
was not spitting at me.” Youth A denied ever being spit on by
Supervisor or any other staff. Youth A reported he has never
seen Supervisor spit at any youth. Youth A described Supervisor
as a “good staff” and stated Supervisor “would never spit on us
[kids]. Youth A reported he could not recall why Supervisor was
yelling or what Supervisor was saying. Youth A stated he did not
have any concerns with the restraint.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 19, 2025. Youth B described seeing Youth A spray
ketchup at Staff 1 and around the house. Youth B reported it took
Staff 1 “a long time to get the ketchup bottle away from [Youth A].”
Youth B stated after Staff 1 got the ketchup bottle Youth B
punched Staff 1 and was placed in a restraint. Youth B denied
seeing Staff 1 wipe ketchup on Youth A.
Youth B reported Supervisor came to assist Staff 1 with
restraining Youth A. Youth B described Supervisor saying
something to Youth A and ended up spitting on Youth A. Youth B
stated, “it wasn’t on purpose.” Youth B reported Supervisor was
talking loud and spit “just came out his mouth.” Youth B stated he
2

could not recall what Supervisor was saying. Youth B denied ever
seeing Supervisor spit on Youth A or any other youth.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 19, 2025. Youth C reported Youth A grabbed a ketchup
bottle and was spraying ketchup all over the floor. Youth C stated
Staff 1 grabbed the ketchup bottle and put it in the staff office.
Youth C denied seeing Staff 1 wipe any ketchup on Youth A.
Youth C denied seeing Supervisor spit on Youth A during a
restraint. Youth C stated Supervisor was talking with Youth A
during a restraint but never spit on or at Youth A. Youth C denied
ever seeing Supervisor spit at any youth during a restraint.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on February
19, 2025. Staff 1 reported Youth A was upset about not getting
his art kit. Staff 1 stated Youth A grabbed a ketchup bottle and
threatened to spray staff and youth. Staff 1 described ignoring
Youth A at first but than Youth A started to spray the ketchup on
Staff 1. Staff 1 reported he grabbed the ketchup bottle and said,
“Here have some ketchup” and put some on Youth A’s shoulder/
arm area. Staff 1 stated, “It was not my proudest moment.” Staff
1 reported Youth A can be difficult to work with and thought it was
a teachable moment, a natural consequence. Staff 1 denied
being trained to handle the situation like he did and stated he
should have used different tactics.
Staff 1 described Youth A being restrained later in the day after
the ketchup incident because Youth A was going after another
youth in the house. Staff 1 reported Youth A grabbed a pan, was
going after the youth and hit Staff 1 with the pan. Staff 1 stated
Youth A punched and eventually hit Staff 1 in the head. Staff 1
reported he placed Youth A in a restraint and Supervisor arrived at
the house to assist with the restraint. Staff 1 described Supervisor
being loud, matching Youth A’s energy, and when talking spit
came out of Supervisor’s mouth. Staff 1 denied seeing Supervisor
spit on Youth A. Staff 1 stated spit was just coming out of
Supervisor’s mouth as he was talking to Youth A.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 19, 2025. Supervisor denied being at the house when
the ketchup incident took place. Supervisor reported he came to
the house to assist with Youth A who was escalated. Supervisor
stated Youth A was hitting Staff 1 and kicking Supervisor so was
placed in two-person restraint. Supervisor described raising his
voice, asking Youth A what his plan was to calm down and spit
3

came out as he was talking to Youth A. Supervisor denied spitting
on Youth A. Supervisor stated, “I didn’t mean to spit on him.”
Supervisor reported after the restraint he followed up with Youth A
and apologized.
Documents Reviewed:
• Staff 1’s personnel file: There was no disciplinary record
and Staff 1 completed the required Aegis training on
5/15/2024.
• Supervisor’s personnel file: There was one disciplinary
action not related to interactions with youth dated
07/09/2023. Supervisor completed the required Aegis
training on 6/20/2024.
• Incident Report 207810239 for incident dated 2/15/25 for
Youth A. Incident report was consistent with youths, Staff
1, and Supervisor’s interviews.
• Eagle Village Staff Code of Conduct Policy. Policy outlines
staff will treat residents and coworkers with respect and
dignity in words and action. All staff will strive to be
professional in the behavior, conversation and all
interactions with others.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, Staff 1 admitted to putting ketchup on Youth A’s
arm/shoulder area.
The facility is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews described Supervisor had spit come out of his mouth as
he was talking to Youth A, not actually spitting at or on Youth A.
Conclusion Violation Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
